description: The focus of this course is on the valuation of companies. Topics discussed include discounted cash flow techniques and valuation using alternative valuation techniques such as price multiples. Emphasis is on developing the required information for valuation from financial statements and other information sources.
name: CORPORATE VALUATION

values.comments:
The focus of this course is on the valuation of companies. Topics discussed include discounted cash flow techniques and valuation using alternative valuation techniques such as price multiples. Emphasis is on developing the required information for valuation from financial statements and other information sources. Prerequisites: FNCE 100, FNCE 101, and STAT 101-102 (Financial accounting, ACCT 201, recommended).
Students felt that they “definitely learned a lot about accounting and valuation from this class.” While it was a “tedious course,” the “knowledge gained out of it is worth the effort and the time.” It was overall a “very strong course that significantly improved [students’] knowledge.” Students left the class feeling they “finally really [understand] the concepts of cash flows, betas, returns etc.” “The valuation project was an extremely rewarding hands-on experience.” Students who have had investment banking experience thought the “detail taught in this class was far and beyond what is expected at the professional level.”
Professor Glode was “very helpful and enthusiastic about the course which made it much easier to understand the topics covered. “ He is “very knowledgeable” and “tries his best to teach his class well.” Lectures were “conveyed in an understandable manner, well-explained, and backed-up with examples.” However, “he could have dealt with students' questions more professionally.”
The course was “difficult, because it requires a lot of work but at the same time is the most valuable aspect.” The valuation project comprises “30% of the course grade” but takes “months to complete” and a significant amount of work. Some students felt that class material did not “adequately prepare students for the main project,” as each company has nuances that may not be covered in class. “It was clear that teams that did well had had prior valuation experience.” “Having a competent team that you get along with is crucial because it makes delegation easier and the long hours with each other more enjoyable.” Overall, students felt that this was a “very intellectually stimulating course that is definitely worth doing regardless of what major the student is undertaking.”  This class is “less valuable for people who already have investment banking experience but very valuable for those intending to try it out.”
